awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: Strategically Engaging Private Institutions at Building Research Infrastructure, Networks and Knowledge (BRINK) in the Emergence of Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The unique responsibilities of Research Administration and Research Development (RARD) administrators, as professionals who support collaboration across diverse research disciplines, support faculty at all stages of their academic careers, and who engage with external partners and sponsors, make RARDs a critical human resource investment in growing the research enterprise. This project will train RARD professionals to use a strengths-based approach, called SOAR  (Strengths, Opportunities, Aspirations, and Results) in strategic thinking, planning, leading, and facilitating conversations that spark innovation, collaboration, and support research engagement within and across emerging research institutions to provide mentoring, shared expertise and resources required for growth. Lawrence Technological University in partnership with University of South Florida and Michigan Independent Colleges and Universities network will host the Building Research Infrastructure, Networks, and Knowledge (BRINK) conferences to provide training over a year-long period via in-person and virtual workshops and will host a symposium to showcase the results of participant’s implemented capacity-building projects within and across emerging research institutions. BRINK addresses emerging research institutional barriers by increasing capacity through a synergistic approach that optimizes training, collective mentoring, and symposia.
 
The basis of BRINK’s RARD training is the SOAR framework and method of Appreciative Inquiry (AI), a practice of asking generative questioning and use of positive framing, to involve all stakeholders in strategic planning and organizational change. Initial workshops will be training in SOAR, individual assessment of strengths (the SOAR Profile), and setting objectives for individual projects. The project will engage Research Administration and Research Development (RARD) administrators from Michigan’s emerging research institutions who will learn how to use SOAR to think and plan strategically about the practices and processes within their respective research enterprise. Three iterations of follow-on 90-day mentoring sessions will share interim successes on projects and strategies supporting implementation. The final symposium will provide an opportunity to share successfully practiced strategies that specifically contribute to the research community’s capacity to support all emerging research institutions. The BRINK project activities will promote the development of a sustainable network of emerging research institutions in Michigan. The Florida Research Development Alliance is a partner and model for building this sustainable structure. The methods and results of the BRINK program will be widely disseminated with the goal of promoting networked approaches to building research development and support capacity within emerging research institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. While Building Research Infrastructure, Networks, and Knowledge (BRINK) is a conference grant, a major goal is to build the sustained capacity of institutions in Michigan to engage its smaller institutions in research through networking its research administrative and research development (RARD) professionals. The initial launch was hosted at Lawrence Technological University, June 16-19, 2024. We were pleasantly surprised at the range of institutional types engaged in the conference, as the conference attracted participants from large and small universities, as well as remote universities in Michigan's upper peninsula.  The conference kicked off with an all-day Body of Knowledge workshop delivered by the Research Administration Certification Council (RACC) on the Certified Financial Research Administrator exam. Subsequent workshops included: Keynote presentation on ARIS Toolkit by Megan Heitmann;  How Grass Roots Frow: Watering Your Network, an overview of the Florida Research Development Alliance by Joshua Roney; Learning to SOAR: How to Achieve Excellence in Your Organization by Jackie Stavros; NIH, NSF and Uniform Guidance update by Kathryn Wrench; SOAR into your Potential with Purpose by Jackie Stavros; Leverage Self-awareness of Your SOAR Capacity workshop by Matt Cole. A session on Outcomes and Impacts from the USF Summer Grant Writing Workshops was led by Sandra Justice. The 2024 BRINK conference concluded with the NSF GRANTED Bootcamp led by Dina Myers Stroud.

The 2024 BRINK workshops were designed to train RARD professionals in techniques of positive engagement using SOAR, a strengths-based approach to strategic thinking, planning, leading, and conversations that facilitate innovation, collaboration, and engagement. Additionally, 50 BRINK conference attendees participated in the SOAR assessment survey.  The resulting SOAR report examined responses across the four elements of SOAR—Strengths (STR), Opportunities (OPP), Aspirations (ASP), and Results (RES)—and Appreciative Inquiry (AI)—based on respondent position (Research Manager, Research Administrator). The implications and recommendations include:

Targeted Interventions for Research Administrators: The variability in their responses, especially in Aspirations, suggests the need for targeted engagement to improve perceived opportunities for growth and development.

Maintaining High Scores in Results (RES): Since Results had the highest ratings, continuing to reinforce and communicate successful organizational outcomes may sustain positive engagement.

Bridging Perception Gaps: If Research Managers consistently report higher scores, it may indicate differences in job roles, organizational support, or leadership expectations that warrant further qualitative investigation.

These findings highlight positive overall perceptions and differences in role-based experiences, particularly between Research Administrators and Research Managers. Addressing areas with high variability, such as Aspirations, could enhance overall organizational engagement and alignment.

Broader Impact. The BRINK program successfully promotes the development of a sustainable network of emerging research institutions in Michigan. The Florida Research Development Alliance is a partner and model for building this sustainable structure. Participants expressed interest in contributing to the development of the Michigan Research Administration and Development network (MiRAD). A quarterly MiRAD newsletter was established to promote visibility and strengthen the connection between institutions. A hybrid conference is planned in 2025 showcasing the emerging Michigan Research Administration and Development (MiRAD) network. The methods and results of the BRINK program were disseminated with the goal of promoting networked approaches to building research development and support capacity within emerging research institutions. 

1. Inspire Action: Mentoring and Strategic Leadership – Leveraging Cross-Institutional Collaborations, workshop. NCURA Regional IV Conference, April 2024, Kathryn Wrench and Sandra Justice.
2. Inspire Action: Strategic Leadership Conversations for Research Administrators and Research Development Professionals, workshop at the 66th NCURA Annual Meeting, August 2024, Sandra Justice and Kathryn Wrench.

3. NSF GRANTED Program Updates: Panel Presentation at the 66th NCURA Annual Meeting, August 2024. Alicia Knoedler, Sandra Justice, Sarah E. Robertson, Kathryn Wrench.
